docs.title: \(LL(1)\) Table Construction
docs.text:
Following is the algorithm to construct a predictive parsing table.1

  • For each production \(A \to \alpha\)
    • For each terminal \(a\) in \(\text{FIRST}(\alpha)\), add \(A \to \alpha\) to \(M[A, a]\).
    • If \(\epsilon \in \text{FIRST}(\alpha)\)
      • \(\$ \in \text{FOLLOW}(A) \implies \text{add } A \to \alpha\) to \(M[A, \$]\).
      • \(b \in \text{FOLLOW}(A) \implies \text{add } A \to \alpha\) to \(M[A, b]\).
  • Make each undefined entry of \(M\) be an error.
id + * ( ) $ E E → TE' E → TE' E' E' → +TE' E' → ε E' → ε T T → FT' T → FT' T' T' → ε T' → *FT' T' → ε T' → ε F F → id F → (E)

docs.title: Left Factoring
docs.text:
Consider the grammar

E ? T + E | T
T ? int   | int T | (E)

It is impossible to predict because for both T and E, the productions that from same symbols. (i.e. for T, it is int and for E, it is T). A grammar must be left factored before use for predictive parsing.1

docs.title: Procedure
docs.text: If \(\alpha \neq \epsilon\), replace all productions \(A \to \alpha \beta_1 | \alpha \beta_2 | \ldots | \alpha \beta_n | \gamma\) with \(A \to \alpha Z | \gamma\) and \(Z \to \beta_1 | \beta_2 | \ldots | \beta_n\) where \(Z\) is the new non terminal.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Consider the following fragment of expression grammar.

Factor -> id
       |  id [ExprList]
       |  id (ExprList)

After left factoring, the grammar becomes

Factor -> id Args
Args   -> [ExprList]
       |  (ExprList)
       |  e

Given a context free grammar which doesn't meet the \(LL(1)\) condition, it is undecidable whether or not an equivalent \(LL(1)\) grammar exists or not.

docs.title: Bottom up Parsing
docs.text:
It is more general and preferred method in practice and is also called LR parsing.

  • L means tokens1 are read from left to right.
  • R means the parser2 constructs a right most derivation.

These parsers2 don't need left factored grammar and can handle left recursion grammars.3

A derivation consists of a series of rewrite steps

\[S \implies \gamma_0 \implies \gamma_1 \implies \ldots \implies \gamma_{n - 1} \implies \gamma_n \implies \text{sentence}\]
  • If \(\gamma\) contains \(\ge 1\) non terminals4 then it is called sentential form.
  • If \(\gamma\) contains only terminals4 then it is called a sentence.

These parsers2 work by starting from the sentence and working up to the start symbol.

docs.title: Shift Reduce: the Stack
docs.text:
The shift action pushes a terminal1 on the stack. Reduce

  • Pops one or more symbols from the stack (right hand side of production1)
  • Pushes a non terminal1 on the stack (left hand side of production1)

docs.title: Discovering Handles
docs.text:
The upper edge of a partially constructed parse tree2 is called its upper frontier. The parser3 must find some substring \(\beta\) of the upper frontier where

  • \(\beta\) is the right hand side of some production \(A \to \beta\) and
  • \(A \to \beta\) is one step in right most derivation of input stream

Each potential match is represented as a pair \(<A \to \beta, k>\) where \(k\) is the position on the tree2's current frontier of the right end of \(\beta\). This pair is called the handle of the bottom up parser.3

docs.title: Handle Pruning
docs.text:
The use of stack simplifies the parsing algorithm in 2 ways.

  1. It trivializes the problem of managing space for the frontier by pushing the input characters at top of the stack.
  2. It makes sure that all handles occur with their right ends at the top of the stack, eliminating the need to keep track of position \(k\).

docs.title: Shift-reduce Parsing Algorithm
docs.text:
push $ onto stack sym ← nextToken() repeat until 

stack.push("$")
sym = nextToken()

while (not (sym == "$" and stack[1] == "G")): # Goal symbol right above $ symbol
    if (stack.top() == "A -> B"):
        stack.pop() # pops all B
        stack.push("A")
    else if (sym != "$"):
        stack.push(sym)
        sym = nextToken()
    else:
        # report error and halt

docs.title: Handles
docs.text:
The handle finding mechanism is crucial in bottom-up parsing,1 where the parser2 tracks potential handles- substrings matching the right-hand side of productions to guide reductions. Parsing1 starts with <Goal → Expr,1> as a potential handle,3 and as it proceeds, new handles3 emerge, representing suffixes that can be reduced.

Count Handle 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9

The notation reveals identical handles and allows tracking future handle discovery. For example, in step 6, the parser state Expr → Expr – • Term shows it has recognized Expr – and is waiting for Term. Once Term is shifted, the handle completes. Each production with k symbols has k + 1 potential handle positions, marked by placeholders between or around symbols.

  • Expr → Expr • – Term
  • Expr → Expr – • Term

docs.title: What is System Programming?
docs.text: It is the study of techniques which facilitates the acquisition of data from input devices such as peripherals and output devices which maybe result of processing performed by an application.

docs.title: Three Layered Approach
docs.text:
System Programmer can do either of the following:

  1. Invoke the hardware directly
  2. Use BIOS routines to invoke the hardware
  3. Use OS routines to invoke BIOS routines which invoke the hardware.

docs.title: Methods of I/O
docs.text:
The hardware can be programmed to perform I/O in 3 ways.

  • Programmed I/O
  • Interrupt driven I/O
  • Direct Memory Access

In case of programmed I/O, the CPU waits for I/O device to be free so it can perform an operation and remains tied to it, mostly idling.

In case of Interrupt driven I/O, the CPU continues dealing with the processes and when the I/O device is available, it generates an interrupt1 which invokes an Interrupt Service Routine(ISR) which grabs the CPU's attention to perform the I/O operation. This allows I/O device to be busy doing the I/O operation and CPU to be busy doing the processing.

Normally, the data is transferred as follows:

  1. I/O → CPU register (1 bus cycle)
  2. CPU register → Memory (1 bus cycle)

A DMA (Direct Memory Access) controller can control the system bus, allow data transfer in 1 bus cycle as I/O \(\leftrightarrow\) CPU.

docs.title: I/O Controller
docs.text:
I/O is not connected to CPU directly but rather through a middle man called I/O Controller.

The functions of this I/O controller are as follows

  • I/O control signals
  • Buffering
  • Error Correction and Detection

Some of these controllers include

  • DMA controller
  • Interrupt controller
  • Programmable Peripheral Interface (PPI)
  • Interval Timer
  • Universal Asynchronous Receiver Transmitter

docs.title: Operating Systems
docs.text: Operating systems use data structures or tables for management of computer resources.

docs.title: File Management
docs.text:
The directory structure is formed by data structures such as

  • FAT (versions include 12, 16, 32-bits)
  • BPB(BIOS parameter block)
  • DPB(drive parameter block)
  • FCBs (file control block)

docs.title: Memory Management
docs.text:
Standard PC operate in two mode in terms of memory which are

  • Real Mode
  • Protected Mode

In real mode, the CPU can only access first MB of the memory. To control this section of memory, DOS uses following data structures

  • FCB (File control block)
  • PSP (Program segment prefix)

Operating systems operating in protected mode make use of following data structures

  • Local Descriptor Table
  • Global Descriptor Table
  • Interrupt Descriptor Table

docs.title: Viruses and Vaccines
docs.text:
There are various types of viruses but we will discuss those which embed themselves within the program or executable code which are

  • Executable file viruses
  • Partition Table or boot sector viruses

docs.title: Device Drivers
docs.text:
A device driver contains the routines which perform I/O operations on the device.

CPU sends data on the data lines and then sends the STROBE signal to the device. This then allows the device to get the input data and start its output and while it is busy, it sends BUSY signal to CPU. The data ready signal allows CPU to take input from the device.

docs.title: Types
docs.text:
• Hardware (invoked by hardware controller generally)
  • Software (invoked by software)

docs.title: Mechanism
docs.text:
• Operating system
    • DOS's kernel is io.sys which loads at boot time.
    • Window's kernel is kernel32.dll or kernel.dll.
  • Interrupts supported by ROM BIOS are loaded in ROM section of the main memory which starts at location F000:0000H.
  • Some device drivers also come with interrupts which are loaded into ISR.

A standard PC has 256 interrupts which are placed inside a 1024-byte sized table called Interrupt Vector Table (IVT) where each address is 4 bytes long. So the interrupt number is used to index into IVT.

Potential MCQs

These MCQs are mentioned in the original text, not this website

  1. Computer Programming is divided into two categories.

docs.title: 02. Interrupt1 Mechanism
docs.text:
Dated: 08-09-2025

For an interrupt1 invocation, the following registers are pushed.

  1. IP
  2. CS
  3. FLAGS

docs.title: The Interrupt1 Vector Table
docs.text:
Each entry in the table contains a far address of an interrupt handler hence there is a maximum of \(256\) handlers however each handler can have a number of services within itself.

Interrupt Vector Table

The IVT resides in 0000:0000H pair (segment:offset pair). Each entry contains a far address which consists of first 2 bytes (lower word) for offset and 2 bytes (higher word) for segment address.

\[\text{Interrupt Vector} = \text{Segment Address} : \text{Interrupt Index} \times 4\] Computing vector of INT21H

\(\text{Interrupt Vector} = 0000 : 0021H \times 4 = 0000 : 0084H\)

docs.title: Location of ISRs (Interrupt Service routines)
docs.text:
There are 3 kinds of ISRs depending upon the entity implementing them.

  1. BIOS (Basic I/O services) ISRs
  2. DOS ISRs

  3. ISRs provided by third party device drivers

  4. ROM BIOS address starts from F000:0000H.

  5. Interrupts1 provided by DOS are in io.sys and msdos.sys and provided by windows are in kernel32.dll and kernel.dll
  6. The interrupts1 provided by device drivers reside in the memory occupied by those drivers.

docs.title: Interrupt1 Invocation
docs.text:
After an interrupt1 has been invoked, the CPU takes a certain series of steps.

  • Push Flags, CS, IP Registers, Clear Interrupt Flag.
  • Use \(\text{Interrupt Index} \times 4\) and \(0\) for segment value.
  • This value is interrupt vector and not the ISR itself.
  • Use lower word as offset and move into IP
  • Use higher word as segment address and move into CS = 0:[offset + 2]
  • Branch to ISR and perform the I/O operation.
  • Return to the point of interrupt by popping 6 bytes (of FLAGS, CS, IP).

docs.title: Parameter Passing into Software Interrupts1
docs.text: The parameters are passed through registers.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Interrupt:1 21H Service: 09H

It is used to print a string ending by a $ symbol.

docs.title: Inputs
docs.text:
• AH = 0x09
  • DS = Segment Address of the string
  • DX = Offset Address of the string

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
String ending with $.

Following code example works with a 16-bit DOS compiler.

#include <stdio.h>
#include <BIOS.h>
#include <DOS.h>
#include <conio.h>

char st[80] = {"Hello World$"};

void main () {
    clrsrc(); //to clear the screen contents
    _DX = (unsigned int) st; // pseudo variable
    _AH = 0x09;              // pseudo variable
    geninterrupt(0x21);
    getch(); //waits for the user to press any key
}

docs.title: The int86() function
docs.text:
struct full {
    unsigned int ax;
    unsigned int bx;
    unsigned int cx;
    unsigned int dx;
};

struct half {
    unsigned char al;
    unsigned char bl;
    unsigned char cl;
    unsigned char dl;
    unsigned char ah;
    unsigned char bh;
    unsigned char ch;
    unsigned char dh;
};

typedef union tarREG {
    struct full x;
    struct full h;
} REGS;

The int86() has 3 parameters.

  1. Interrupt1 number
  2. Reference to REGS union2 containing the parameter values.
  3. Reference to REGS union2 which will contain the register values which are to be expected as the result of interrupt.1

docs.title: 03. Use of IRSs for C Library Functions
Example
docs.text:
Interrupt:1 21H Service: 42H

#include <stdio.h>
#include <fcntl.h>
#include <io.h>
#include <BIOS.h>
#include <DOS.h>

unsigned int handle;

void main () {
    union REGS regs;
    unsigned long int size;
    handle = open("c:\\abc.txt", O_RDONLY);
    regs.x.bx = handle;
    regs.h.ah = 0x42;
    regs.h.al = 0x02; //correction
    regs.x.cx = 0;
    regs.x.dx = 0;
    int86(0x21, &regs, &regs);

    *((int*)(&size)) = regs.x.ax;
    *(((int*)(&size)) + 1) = regs.x.dx;

    printf("Size is %d", size);
}

docs.title: Network
docs.text: A network is defined as a system of computers connected together through a single transmission technology. The connected computers can communicate with each other through receiving or sending information.

docs.title: Internet
docs.text: The internet is defined as a set of networks, connected by routers which manage traffic between different computers.

docs.title: Classification of Networks
docs.text: The network can be classified by following: 1. Size 2. Connectivity 3. Medium 4. Mobility

docs.title: By Size
docs.text: According to the size, there are 2 classifications. 1. LAN (Local Area Network): It covers a small area such as a building. 2. WAN (Wide Area Network): It covers large areas such as cities or countries.

docs.title: By Connectivity
docs.text: According to connectivity, there are 2 classifications. 1. Point-to-Point 2. Broadcast

docs.title: Point-to-Point
docs.text: This comprises of 2 topologies. 1. Star: In this topology, computers are connected to a central hub. 2. Tree: In this topology, computers are connected in such a way that the structure appears like a tree.

docs.title: Broadcast
docs.text: This comprises of 2 technologies 1. Satellite or Radio: In this technology, computers are connected through satellite through radio waves. 2. Ring: In this technology, computers are connected in a ring structure.

docs.title: By Medium
docs.text:
By medium, network are classified as such: 1. Copper Wire 2. Co-axial cable 3. Optical Fiber 4. Radio Waves

These can differ from each other depending on following parameters: - speed - range - topology - Installation and maintenance cost

docs.title: By Mobility
docs.text: There are 2 types of networks. 1. Fixed networks 2. Mobile networks

docs.title: Issues
docs.text:
• Location and Tracking
  • Semi persistent connections
  • Complex administration
  • Billing as devices
  • Users move across the networks

docs.title: Networks in Daily Life
docs.text: network is being used in daily life as follows:

docs.title: Business
docs.text:
• Advertisements
  • Production
  • Shipping
  • Planning
  • Billing
  • Accounting

docs.title: Homes
docs.text: network can be used to control home appliances through phone.

docs.title: Government
docs.text: Following use network for communication. 1. Federal 2. Local 3. Military

docs.title: Education
docs.text: We have libraries or LMS systems which we can access from home.

docs.title: Complexity of Network Systems
docs.text: Following are the reasons why network are complex,

docs.title: Many Technologies Exist
docs.text: There are multiple standards developed by multiple companies which result into incompatible technologies.

docs.title: No Single Underlying Theory or Model
docs.text: Instead of having a theory, we have similarities or differences between the network hardware and software.

docs.title: Models Are either way Too Simple or Complex
docs.text: Either the models are way to simple that it is hard to spot differences or either they are way too much complicated and are not simplified enough.

docs.title: No Simple or Uniform Terminology
docs.text: There is no uniform terminology used for same features. Different technologies with similar features use different terminologies.

docs.title: Concentrate on Understanding the Concept
docs.text: An example is: instead of looking at how different protocols handle congestion, look at what congestion itself is.

docs.title: Learning the Network Terminology
docs.text: Focus on the breath, not the depth. Understand the illustrations. New terminology is introduced with new concepts so learning those can make life easier.

docs.title: Multicasting
docs.text:
There are problems with broadcasting. It wastes CPU time to discard the frames for the computers who didn't need the message.

In multicast, the interface hardware is programmed in a way to accept multicast address. The frames are not directly forwarded to the CPU.

There are 3 types of frames the interface hardware now deals with: 1. Multicast frames. 2. Broadcast frames. 3. Frames that were directly destined to the stations (through physical address).

docs.title: Multicast Addressing
docs.text: Example: imagine 2 computers running an audio application. Their interface is programmed to accept the audio frames. Other computers will ignore the frames, who are not running that audio application.

docs.title: Identifying Packet Contents
docs.text: There needs to be a way for destination to know how to interpret the incoming frames.

docs.title: Explicit Frame Type
docs.text: In this type, the identifying value is included with the frame which describes the frame data.

docs.title: Implicit Frame Type
docs.text: In this type, the frame data has to be read and its type is deduced from that data.

docs.title: Header Frame Format
docs.text:
This figures shows the Ethernet frame format Those numbers represent bytes.

Fields Purpose Preamble Receiver Synchronization Destination Address Identifies intended receiver Source Address Hardware address of sender Frame Type Type of data carried in the frame Data Frame Payload CRC 32-bit CRC code

docs.title: Frame without Type Fields
docs.text: Some LAN technologies do not use the frame type field. This causes all the computers in the network to agree upon using one single data format.

docs.title: Encoding Data Type
docs.text: The data type is encoded within the frame data.

docs.title: IEEE 802.2 LLC
docs.text: This standard uses Logical Link Control Sub Network Attached Point header. OUI stands for organizationally unique identifier.

docs.title: Unknown Types
docs.text: Some computers might not have the protocol type installed which makes them blind to the type of frame they are receiving. Hence, they discard it.

docs.title: Network Analyzers
docs.text:
A network analyzer is also called network monitor or network sniffer. It is used to analyze the performance of a network or debug it. It shows information like capacity utilization, frame distribution size, collision rates, token circulation time etc.

A computer can be configured as promiscuous mode which allows it to see all frames (for analysis).

docs.title: Interface Hardware
docs.text: The LAN transmission speed is faster than the CPU speeds.

docs.title: Network Interface Hardware
docs.text: Since CPU cannot keep up with the network speeds, we need network-interface-card or network-adaptor-card (NIC). It connects to the physical network.

docs.title: NIC and Network Hardware
docs.text: NICs cannot be used for different network hardware. Example: An NIC made for Ethernet won't work with a Token Ring.

docs.title: NIC and CPU Processing
docs.text: Some NICs contain their own micro-processors. The system CPU sends instructions to NIC to transmit data.

docs.title: Connection between NIC and Physical Network
docs.text:
1. The NIC contains all the circuitry to connect to the physical medium.
  2. The NIC has a wire which connects to additional circuitry which connects to the physical medium.

The Thin Ethernet and 10 Base-T Ethernet are both Ethernet.

docs.title: Thick Ethernet Wiring
docs.text: The thick ethernet uses coaxial cable, connected by transceivers which are connected to NICs through AUI cable (also known as drop cable). Which carries digital and control signals to the transceivers. Which generate analogue signals. Which are terminated by the terminators to avoid signal reflections.

docs.title: Thin Ethernet Wiring
docs.text: The transceivers are built directly into the NIC which use BNC-T connectors.

docs.title: 10 Base - T
docs.text: It is also called twisted wire pair or TP Ethernet.

docs.title: Hubs
docs.text: These are extension of connections with multiplexing concept. They are sometimes called Ethernet-in-a-box

docs.title: Protocol Software and Ethernet Wiring
docs.text: All wiring technologies use identical Ethernet specifications. Which means they use same frame formats. They use same CSMA/CD algorithms.

docs.title: Comparison of Wiring Scheme
docs.text: The transceivers allow computers to be powered off or disconnected from the network without disrupting it.

docs.title: Topologies and Network Technologies
docs.text: The twisted wire pair is physically a star topology but logically, it is a bus topology. The token ring is physically a star topology but logically, it is a ring topology.

docs.title: Filtering Incoming Frames
docs.text: The analyzers use filters to capture certain frames which match the filtering criteria and ignores the rest.

docs.title: Advantages and Disadvantages of Wiring Schemes
docs.text: The figure contains 3 schemes as follows: 1. Thin 2. Thick 3. Twisted pair

docs.title: Reliable
docs.text: The connections which use transceivers allow the computers to be disconnected without disturbing the whole network.

docs.title: Cost
docs.text: The twisted wire pair is cheapest. The Thicknet is the most expensive and is no longer used.

docs.title: Logical Topology
docs.text: It is defined by specific network technology.

docs.title: Physical Topology
docs.text: It is defined by wiring scheme.

docs.title: Network Interface Card and Wiring Schemes
docs.text: The cable used for wiring should match the following: 1. The intended data rate 2. The distance between devices 3. The amount of em-noise 4. Anticipated future needs 5. Cost

docs.title: Wiring Schemes and other Network Technologies
docs.text:
• The local talk technology uses hubs (physically star) to implement a logically bus topology.
  • The IBM's Token Ring technology uses hubs (physically star) to implement a logically ring topology.

docs.title: Distance Limitation and LAN Design
docs.text: The electrical signals get weaker as they travel through the cable and the delays must be short to enable the CSMA/CS and token passing etc. But usually, there is a need of extension beyond the normal length limit.

docs.title: LAN Extension
docs.text: Most techniques use hardware is used to extend the diameter of the LAN medium.

docs.title: Fiber Optic Extension
docs.text: The fiber modems are responsible for conversions between light and digital signals. The fiber optic spans over kilometers with minimal delay and maximum bandwidth.

docs.title: Repeaters
docs.text:
As the signals travel, they get weakened. Therefore, repeaters re-transmit the signal.

As the figure suggests, 1 repeaters doubles the max length meanwhile 2 repeaters triples the max length.

Although infinite length can be achieved but it introduces delay which disturbs the CSMA/CD. Therefore, the Ethernet standard specifies that no more than 4 repeaters should be used to connect 2 stations.

docs.title: Disadvantage
docs.text: repeaters only amplify and re-transmit. This also includes collision errors etc.

docs.title: Bridges
docs.text:
These consist of following components: 1. 2 NICs 2. CPU 3. Memory 4. ROM

It runs the code stored in its ROM. It connects 2 LAN segments, listens to all the traffic and transmits only valid frames unlike repeaters.

docs.title: Frame Filtering
docs.text: Most bridges are self learning. They automatically add addresses of computers to their address list.

docs.title: Startup
docs.text: When the bridge boots up, its address list is empty. This state is called startup state.

docs.title: Steady State
docs.text: When the bridge has received at least one frame from every computer, its address list is built. This state is called steady state.

docs.title: Planning a Bridge
docs.text: Since bridges are used to divide LAN into segments, the computers who communicate frequently can be placed into same segment. This improves the performance of the network because traffic on one segment does not affects the traffic on other segment.

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
1. The fiber optic connecting both buildings doesn't need to be disturbed while connecting or disconnecting computers to the network.
  2. Traffic at one building doesn't affects the other building.

docs.title: Building across Longer Distance
docs.text: Since the bandwidth is very low, the bridge has to store data into its memory and wait till it can be send to the satellite for communication but it may run out of memory. Therefore, the communication software waits for a response after sending few frames.

docs.title: A Cycle Bridges
docs.text:
Sometimes, a network can become cyclic as such:

Problem here is that if a broadcast signal is sent, it never terminates and keeps looping around, causing infinite copies.

docs.title: Distributed Spanning Tree
docs.text: In this cyclic case, the bridges communicate with each other and automatically decide through DST algorithm that which bridge will not forward the broadcast frames and which one will do.

docs.title: Switching
docs.text:
A hub simulates a shared medium meanwhile a switch simulates a bridged LAN while each segment contains 1 computer only.

When a hub is used, only 1 pair of computers can talk at a time. When a switch is used, any number of pairs of computers can talk at the same time.

docs.title: Combining Switches and Hubs
docs.text: To reduce the cost, a number of computers can be connected to distributed hubs which later can be connected to a switch.

docs.title: Bridging and Switching with other Technologies
docs.text: These devices are also available for other technologies like: - FDDI - Token Ring

docs.title: WAN Technologies and Routing
docs.text: The LAN cannot be arbitrarily expanded. We need other technologies to overcome the distances.

docs.title: Characterization of Networks
docs.text: There are 3 characteristics of a network:

docs.title: Local Area Network
docs.text: It is used in single building.

docs.title: Metropolitan Area Network
docs.text: it is used in single city

docs.title: Wide Area Network
docs.text: It is used over country or even continental levels.

docs.title: Packet Switches
docs.text:
A packet switch consists of: 1. Network Interfaces 2. Memory 3. Program dedicated for function switching

Packet Switches can connect to other Packet Switches or computers. The speed between the switches is faster as compared to connections between a packet switch and a computer.

docs.title: Packet Switches as a Building Blocks
docs.text: Many packet switches can be connected together to form a WAN.

docs.title: Store and Forward
docs.text: The packet switch contains memory which holds data on queue in case there is traffic. After the traffic is low, it then forwards data to other packet switches or computers.

docs.title: Physical Addressing in a WAN
docs.text:
1. The data is transmitted in packets equivalent to frames.
  2. Each packet has a format with header.
  3. The packet header includes destination and source addresses.
  4. Many WANs use hierarchical addressing for efficiency. One part of address identifies destination switch. Other part of address identifies port on switch.

docs.title: Next Hop Forwarding
docs.text:
1. If the destination is local computer, packet switch delivers computer port.
  2. If the destination is attached to another switch, this packet switch forwards to next hop through connection to another switch.
  3. The choice of another switch is based on destination address in packet.

docs.title: Source Independence
docs.text: The next hop destination does not depend upon the source of the packet. This phenomena is called source independence The packet only have destination information for the next hop, this means even if the network topology changes without notifying the network, it would still work. Hence, increasing the dynamic robustness.

docs.title: Hierarchical Addressing and Routing
docs.text: The process of forwarding packets, is called routing. The information about destinations is kept in routing tables. Figure b represents the routing table of switch 2.

docs.title: Routing in a WAN
docs.text: There are 2 types of switch according to attached computers.

docs.title: Interior Switch
docs.text: This switch has no computers attached to it.

docs.title: Exterior Switch
docs.text:
This switch has computers attached to it.

Both of these switches need routing tables which need 2 things.

docs.title: Universal Routing
docs.text: The table should have next hop for each possible destination.

docs.title: Optimal Routes
docs.text: The table should have next hop for shortest path possible.

docs.title: Modeling a WAN
docs.text: We can model a WAN by representing switches as nodes and direct connections as edges.

docs.title: Redundant and Routing Information
docs.text: Notice how the above figure shows same next hop for node 1. We can collapse the table as such:

docs.title: Building Routing Table
docs.text:
There are 2 methods of building routing tables. 1. Manually 2. Software

There are then further 2 methods of computing these.

docs.title: Static Routing
docs.text: It is not flexible. It is done at boot time It has small network overhead.

docs.title: Dynamic Routing
docs.text: It can work around network failures automatically. It allows automatic updates by the programmers.

docs.title: Computing Shortest Path in a Graph
docs.text: We use Djikstra's 1 algorithm to compute the shortest path.

docs.title: Distributed Route Computation
docs.text: If a node fails then the switch updates its routing table information to avoid the failed hardware.

docs.title: Distance Vector Routing
docs.text: The switches periodically broadcast topology information throughout the network. Then other switches update their routing tables according to the information received.

docs.title: Link-State Routing
docs.text: The network topology is separated from route computations. switches send link-state information about local connections and then they build their routing tables

docs.title: Distance Vector Routing
docs.text:
• Simple to implement
  • switch updates its own routing table first
  • It is used in RIP.

docs.title: Link State Algorithm
docs.text:
• Complex to implement
  • switch performs independent computations.
  • it is used in OSPF.

docs.title: ARPANET
docs.text: Began in 1960s, it was funded by Advanced Research Project Agency, which is an organization of US defense department.

docs.title: X.25
docs.text: This was standard for connection-oriented networking. It began from IFU which was originally CCITT.

docs.title: Frame Relay
docs.text: It is used for Telco service for delivering blocks of data. It is connection based service and requests Telco to establish the circuit between 2 end points. Its speeds are following: - 56 Kbps - 1.5 Mbps - 100 Mbps

docs.title: SMDS
docs.text: Switched Multi megabit Data Service is also a Telco service. This one is connection less and speed ranges from 1.5 Mbps to 1000 Mbps.

docs.title: ATM
docs.text:
Asynchronous transfer mode was designed for lower jitter, high capacity, audio, video and data. It uses fixed size 48 octets data and 5 octets header.

  1. Read more about Djikstra's Algorithm. ↩

docs.title: Connection-Oriented Networking and ATM
docs.text: ATM is the only technology which meets the common goal of LAN and WAN. It uses connection oriented networking. It provides universal service of audio, video to its customers.

docs.title: Jitter
docs.text: It means variance in transmission delays.

docs.title: Packet Sizes
docs.text:
Large packets cause fewer overheads because a very small portion is used for header information.

Optimum networks use 4 KB packet size. Larger ones cannot be used for audio. Example: If the speed is about

\[s = \frac{125 \micro seconds}{sample}\]

Then to fill one 4 KB packet (assuming each sample is of 8-bit).

\[\frac{125 \micro seconds}{sample} \times 8 \times 4 \times 1000 bits\] \[\frac{125 \micro seconds}{sample} \times 4 \times 1000 \left(8 bits\right)\] \[\frac{125 \micro seconds}{sample} \times 4 \times 1000 samples\] \[0.5 seconds\]

docs.title: ATM Cells
docs.text: Each cell has 53 octets. VPI/VCI fields identify the cells destination. ATM header is about 10% of the cell. Engineers sometimes call the ATM overhead as cell tax.

docs.title: Connection-Oriented Service
docs.text: This paradigm is similar to how telephones are used. In data communication, a binary connection identifier is given to both parties (caller and receiver) to identify the connection.

docs.title: Virtual Channel (or Circuits)
docs.text:
The connections in ATM are called virtual circuits since these are not physical connections but rather depend on the starting values in memory (tables).

The VC (virtual channel) is 24-bit and consists of 2 parts: 1. Virtual Path Identifier (VPI, 8-bit) which identifies a particular path through the network 2. Virtual Channel Identifier (VCI, 16-bit) which identifies the channel in the virtual path being used by the connection.

docs.title: Label Switching
docs.text: As the cells arrive at the ATM, their VPI/VCI is modified by a forwarding table and the VPI/VCI is changed for the cell's trip.

docs.title: Label Writing
docs.text: The above mentioned process is called rewriting. ATM, therefore, is called a label writing or label switching system.

docs.title: Permanent Virtual Circuits
docs.text: ATMs can provide customers with virtual circuits that look like traditional leased digital circuits. Such Parmanent Virtual Circuits last as long as the customer pays periodic fee for em. The forwarding table entries are statically configured and are automatically restored after the power of equipment fails. The term used for this is called provisioning. Provisioning requires 2 steps: 1. To determine each switch that will be taken in the complete path. 2. To choose appropriate VPI/VCI for each step of the path.

docs.title: Establishing an SVC
docs.text: The computer sends a connection request to the switch it is attached to, which later finds a network path to destination and sends along the connection request. Each switch in the path chooses a VPI/VCI to establish a path to the destination and after that, a message is sent back to the original PC indicating that the SVC is ready. If any of the switches fails, an error message is sent back to the original PC.

docs.title: Signaling
docs.text: The networking is not only used for data communication but there is also control messages communicated. The term used for such communication is called signaling.

docs.title: Providing Desired QoS
docs.text: These are specified at the time of connection setup. The switches then reserve resources and hence are never altered. If a switch fails to reserve resources, an error message is sent back.

docs.title: ATM QoS Specification
docs.text: There are 3 types of these:

docs.title: Constant Bit Rate
docs.text: Used in audio and video since they have predefined maximum data rates.

docs.title: Variable Bit Rate
docs.text: Used in compressed audio and video because the data rates depends on the level of compression being used

docs.title: Available Bit Rate
docs.text: Used in typical applications where data rate is unknown and whatever is available at the time, is used.

docs.title: Resource Sharing
docs.text: Resource sharing means to share resources between different users. Example: In an office, it would be expensive to give printer to each user. Instead, it would be better to have one printer, shared across different users.

docs.title: Goal of Resource Sharing
docs.text: Main goal is to make the resource available to any user regardless of the place of the resource or the user.

docs.title: Tools for Probing the Internet
docs.text: Now a days, there are millions of computers connected to the internet. To check if a computer is online or not, we use tools for probing.

docs.title: Ping
docs.text: This tool sends packets to our target and receives them as well. It also tells us the ip-address of the target computer.

docs.title: Problems with Ping
docs.text: ping sometimes fail and we cannot tell for sure what exactly was the root cause of it since there are multiple possibilities for it to fail. These possibilities are as follows: 1. Remote computer might have a problem. 2. Local computer might have a problem. 3. Ping sometimes fails because of congestion. 4. Some networks reject these packets to save themselves from denial of service attacks.

docs.title: Trace Route
docs.text: This is another tool which provides more details. This tool shows all the computers from source to destination.

docs.title: Cells Vs Packets
docs.text: ATM designers choose cells over packets because: 1. Cells are fixed sized and do not cause memory fragmentation and are simpler to manage. 2. Since packets are of variable lengths, they need additional data to indicate the start and the end. With cells, we can just count them as they arrive. 3. Since the packet sizes are variable, there have to be complex interrupt schemes because they take variable times to complete the transmission.

docs.title: ATM Speed
docs.text: ATMs are designed to operate with optical fibers but can also work with twisted wired pair. The throughput speed is OC-3 (155Mbps).

docs.title: ATM Critique
docs.text:
• ATM is far more expansive than the typical LAN hardware.
  • Connection setup time may be excessive for short communications.
  • Call tax consumes 10% of network capacity.
  • QoS requirements might be unknown, leading to applications picking values that are too high or too low.

docs.title: Network Ownership
docs.text: There are 2 categories

docs.title: Private Network
docs.text: This is also called intranet and is usually a LAN technology, owned by single or multiple organizations.

docs.title: Private Network Architecture
docs.text: It usually includes one or few closely managed external connections. They may restrict access at connections.

docs.title: Managing Private Network
docs.text: An organization buys hardware and hires staff to design, implement and manage the networks.

docs.title: Extending Private Network
docs.text: The large organizations may have separate campuses. They can install cables on their own property. They can also contact leased lines for common carrier.

docs.title: Public Network
docs.text:
This is owned by common carrier such as a phone company. These are networks which are managed by common carriers by using leased lines.

Networks Advantages Disadvantages Public They are flexible There is no decision making equipment or policies Private The owner has complete control over technical decision and policies They are expensive to install and maintain

docs.title: Virtual Private Networks
docs.text: It combines public and private network. It is limited to single organization but they use public connection for connectivity. These connections are sometimes called tunnels or connect sites. Each site sees tunnel as point-to-point link.

docs.title: Guaranteeing Absolute Privacy
docs.text: VPNs packets are encrypted so if an outsider does gets the packets, they will not be able to interpret information inside it.

docs.title: Service Paradigm
docs.text: Each packet in a network needs to follow a format dictated by the hardware which is called interface paradigms or service paradigms There are 2 types of it:

docs.title: Connection Oriented Service
docs.text:
Similar to the telephone systems. End points maintain the connection as long as they are communicating.

One end point requests to communicate and the other one grants the access.

docs.title: Continuous and Burst Traffic
docs.text: The connection does not disappear when data is not sent. The connection for audio and video is designed continuous meanwhile other networks might use burst traffic

docs.title: Simplex and Full Duplex Connection
docs.text: Some connections are full duplex. To establish a simplex connection between 2 computers, there needs to be 2 connections established. one from computer A to B and other one from B to A.

docs.title: Connection Duration and Persistence
docs.text: There are 2 types:

docs.title: Switched Virtual Circuit
docs.text: Computer maintains permanent connection to the network and network makes connections on demand.

docs.title: Permanent Switched Circuit
docs.text: These are originally hard wired and now configured at system unit time.

docs.title: Service Guarantees
docs.text: Some connection-oriented networks might provide guarantees about the service that computer will receive. These can be in form of: - Throughput rate - Maximum packet loss rate - ATM provides statistical guarantee about performance.

docs.title: Stream of Message Interface
docs.text: Some provides streams where there is no boundary over data chunk size such as 60 characters. Others deliver message interface with same sized chunks.

docs.title: Connectionless Service
docs.text: Similar to postal system. End points put data into packets which are sent to network for delivery.

docs.title: Interior and Exterior Service Paradigm
docs.text: Sometimes, the network can use entirely different paradigm externally and internally. For example: ARPANET uses connection-oriented internally and connection-less externally

docs.title: Connectionless
docs.text:
• It has fewer overheads
  • It is easier to implement

docs.title: Connection Oriented
docs.text:
• Accounting is easier
  • Application can learn of network problems immediately

docs.title: Transmission Medium
docs.text: Data is encoded in form of energy and transmitted over a medium called transmission medium. This can be air, wire etc.

docs.title: Copper Wire
docs.text: These show very low resistance to electric current. Example: Twisted wire pair.

docs.title: Coaxial Cable
docs.text: Single wire surrounded by an insulator and a metallic mesh to shield against interference.

docs.title: Types of Transmission Medium
docs.text: Guided: Where the path is physically defined, such as a wire. Unguided: Where the path is air.

docs.title: Optical Fiber
docs.text: It uses light for carrying data.

docs.title: Radio Waves
docs.text: These are used for TV and public radio etc.

docs.title: Geosync Satellites
docs.text: These are placed about 35785 KMs above the surface of the earth and appear stationary as the earth revolves.

docs.title: Low Orbit Satellites
docs.text: They are about 200 or 400 miles above the earth and do not appear stationary as the earth revolves.

docs.title: Microwaves
docs.text: This uses higher frequency as compared to radio waves and can be uni-directed.

docs.title: Infrared
docs.text: These are used for TVs etc. They have very limited range.

docs.title: Local Async Communication
docs.text:
The sender and receiver do not coordinate with each other and receiver should be able to interpret signals anytime it receives them.

The negative voltage represents 1 while 0 is represented by positive voltage.

The standards of communication define the timings and voltage specifications regarding the signals.

The RS-232-C standard is used for modems and keyboards The RS-232 standard is used as serial for async communication.

docs.title: RS-232-C
docs.text:
• Supports wire length of 50 feet.
  • -15V for 1 and +15 for 0.
  • One character is 7 or 8 bits.
  • No delay between character bits.
  • When idle, it puts 1 on the bus.
  • Each character starts with start bit 0 and ends with stop bit 1.

docs.title: Baud Rate
docs.text: It is defined to be number of changes in the signal per second.

docs.title: Frame Errors
docs.text: These occur when the end bits do not occur at the expected times.

docs.title: Full-Duplex Async Communication
docs.text: It uses 2 wires in which 1 carries the data signal and other one carries the return path called ground. The 2 directional communication at same time is called full-duplex communicaion.

docs.title: Modulation
docs.text: The original signal is slightly modified by the transmitter by using a carrier. This process is called modulation.

docs.title: Types of Modulation
docs.text:
1. Amplitude Modulation
  2. Frequency Modulation
  3. Phase Modulation

docs.title: Modem
docs.text: A modem is a device which combines both the modulator and demodulator together.

docs.title: Multiplexing
docs.text: It is the process of passing multiple signals over the same wire by using multiple frequencies.

docs.title: Types of Multiplexing
docs.text:
1. Frequency Division
  2. Wave Division
  3. Time Division

docs.title: Frequency Division
docs.text: Different frequencies are passed onto the same medium

docs.title: Wave Division
docs.text: Same concept but applied to optical fibers.

docs.title: Time Division
docs.text: In this type, the sources take turns to send their data. Meaning they do not send data all at once, rather, they wait for their turns.

docs.title: Packet
docs.text: Computer networks divide the data into blocks or junks called packets. These blocks are helpful for error detection.

docs.title: Problem with Sharing
docs.text: There are many computers connected to a network and some applications require a lot of data transfer which takes a lot of time. Hence, it causes other applications to wait but some applications cannot wait for long periods of time.

docs.title: Solution for Fairness
docs.text: To solve the above mentioned problem, the data is divided into packets and then each computer takes turns to send the data over the shared network. This way, no computer has to experience delays.

docs.title: Packet
docs.text: A packets is a generic term. Each hardware uses different formats of packets.

docs.title: Frames
docs.text: A frame is defined to be a specific packets format for a specific hardware technology. To define this standard, we attach a start and a tail header to the frame.

docs.title: Problems
docs.text: Frames also have some problems in transmission: 1. Missing the end-of-tail means computer has crashed. 2. Missing the start-of-head means computer missed beginning of the message. 3. Bad frame is discarded.

docs.title: Byte Stuffing
docs.text:
Sometimes when a frame is read, the start-of-head or end-of-tail may appear in the frame data itself.

The bytes similar to start-of-head and end-of-tail appearing within the frame can confuse the receiver for the actual frame headers.

The solution for this problem is called byte-stuffing.

To distinguish between the data being sent and the control information such as frame delimiters, the data that is being sent is modified. This technique is called data-stuffing.

docs.title: Types
docs.text: There are 2 types of data-stuffing: 1. byte-stuffing 2. bit-stuffing

docs.title: Byte Stuffing
docs.text:
Each one of the reserved bytes (which indicates the #frame headers) are replaced by 2 unreserved bytes, one of them acts as a prefix.

Note: soh stands for start-of-head, eot stands for end-of-tail.

Original Data Modified Data soh esc x eot esc y esc esc z

docs.title: Bit Stuffing
docs.text: This refers to bit oriented hardware, as opposed to byte-stuffing which is byte oriented hardware.

docs.title: Transmission Error
docs.text: These may occur due to power surges or interference due to which the bytes or bits get corrupted.

docs.title: Error Detection and Correction
docs.text: frame includes additional information which is added by the sender for error detection and correction. The incorrect data is either rejected or it is corrected first and then accepted.

docs.title: Parity Checking
docs.text: This is one of the error detection schemes.

docs.title: Even Parity
docs.text: The number of 1s in the data should be even.

docs.title: Odd Parity
docs.text: The number of 1s in the data should be odd.

docs.title: Parity Bit
docs.text: This is that extra bit that is transmitted along with the data so we can use even-parity or odd-parity.

docs.title: Limitations of Parity Checking
docs.text:
The error detection offered by it is very limited. Imagine the original data: 101101. Due to noise, it gets corrupted to: 101011.

The total number of bits before or after the corruption are still even.

docs.title: Alternative Error Detection Schemes
docs.text: There are other techniques as well but they differ from each other in following aspects: 1. The size of additional information (transmission overhead). 2. Computational complexity of the algorithms (computational overhead). 3. The number of bit errors which can be detected.

docs.title: Checksum
docs.text: In this technique, the data is treated as integers and its arithmetic sum is computed. Then on the receiving end, same thing is done and if the results match then there is no errors.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
It also has limitations.

See how the corrupted data is not detected because the checksum turns out to be same for both.

docs.title: Cyclic Redundancy Check
docs.text: The message data is treated as co-efficient of a polynomial. Then this set of co-efficient is divided by a known polynomial and the remainder of this division is sent to the receiver for checking.

docs.title: Hardware Components Used in CRC
docs.text: There are 2 hardware components it uses. 1. Shift register 2. XOR gate

docs.title: Shift Operation
docs.text: This operation shifts all the bits to the left by one position. Example: This figure represents a 16-bit CRC hardware which uses 3 shift registers and 3 XOR units.

docs.title: Types of Errors
docs.text: CRC can check following errors better than checksum.

docs.title: Vertical Errors
docs.text: These occur due to hardware failure. Example: 2nd bit of each character is damaged.

docs.title: Burst Errors
docs.text: These occur when a small set of bits changes due to some external interference like lightning or an electric motor starting nearby.

docs.title: Frame Format and Error Detection
docs.text: If there is an error in the frame, it is rejected by the receiver.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: In a shared medium, hardware devices need to take turns in able to communicate.

docs.title: Direct Point-to-Point Communication
docs.text: In this mode, each channel connects exactly 2 devices.

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
1. The connection type of individual connections can be different.
  2. Individual connections can choose a different frame format and error detection mechanism etc.
  3. It is easy to enforce security and privacy

docs.title: Disadvantages
docs.text:
1. The no. of connections grow more rapidly than the no. of computers.
  2. For ‘n’ computers connections = (n^2 – n)/2.
  3. Most computers use the same physical path.
  4. Direct point-to-point communication is expensive due to a no. of connections.
  5. Another disadvantage is that adding a new computer to the network requires N-1 new connections as shown in the above figure.

docs.title: Shared Communication Channels
docs.text: The development started in early 1960 and 1970s. For the short distances, the LAN is used because it uses a shared medium which reduces the number of connections, has becoming a cheaper solution. But due to this shared medium, the computers compete against each other to use the channel because they have to wait for their turns. For long distances, the point-to-point approach is used.

docs.title: Locality of Reference Principle
docs.text: This principle helps to predict the communication patterns. There are 2 patterns:

docs.title: Spatial
docs.text: In this pattern, computers which are located nearby are likely to communicate with each other.

docs.title: Temporal
docs.text:
In this pattern, the computers are likely to communicate repeatedly to the same computers.

LAN is effective due to spatial locality of reference.

docs.title: LAN Topologies
docs.text: There are 3 popular LAN topologies:

docs.title: Star
docs.text: In this topology, the devices are attached to the central device called the hub.

docs.title: Ring
docs.text: In this topology, the computers are connected to each other in a closed loop. One computer sends message to 2nd one, the 2nd one sends to 3rd one and so on.

docs.title: Bus
docs.text: In this topology, all the computers are connected to same back-bone cable. The computers have to coordinate to wait for their turns.

docs.title: Ethernet
docs.text: It was invented in 1970s. Intel and others defined it in a standard called DIX standard. It is now managed by IEEE under standard 802.3 which defines the length and voltages etc. It uses bus topology and is also called as a segment which is limited to 500 meters in length. The minimum separation between connections is 3 meters.

docs.title: Ethernet Speeds
docs.text:
• Originally, it was 3 Mbps.
  • Standard now a days is 10 Mbps
  • The fast ethernet operates at 100 Mbps ones
  • But there are also which touches Giga bits per second.

docs.title: Encoding Used in Ethernet
docs.text:
The encoding technique used in it is called manchester.

  • 0 is represented by voltage drop.
  • 1 is represented by voltage increase.

docs.title: Carrier Sense with Multiple Access(CSMA)
docs.text: CSMA is a coordinate technique which tells how the computers communicate over a shared medium. The computers listen to the carrier (they read codes which define the status of the channel). When the carrier channel is idle, the computer starts to communicate.

docs.title: Collision Detection and Back off with CSMA/CD
Collision Detection
docs.text: The phenomena in which multiple frames interfere with each other, is called collision.

docs.title: Ethernet CD
docs.text: For collision detection, Ethernet includes a hardware which detects transmission. It does the following operations: 1. It monitors outgoing signals 2. Grabbled signal is interpreted as a collision

docs.title: Recovery from Collision
docs.text: When a collision is detected by a computer, it sends special signals to all other interfaces that a collision has happened. Then the computers wait for the channel to be idle. If the delay time (the waiting period) is same for both computers, then they will transmit the frames at same time and a collision will happen again. To fix this problem, both the computers choose random delays.

docs.title: Exponential Backup
docs.text: Due to busy medium, collisions might still happen. Therefore, the delays are doubled. It reduces the chances of collision.

docs.title: 802.11 Wireless LANs and CSMA/CA
docs.text: The IEEE 802.11 wireless LAN standard uses radio signals at 2.4 GHz. Its data rate is 11 Mbps. The older device uses radio signals at 900 MHz with data rate 2 Mbps.

docs.title: Limited Connectivity With Wireless
docs.text:
Not all participants might be able to communicate with each other. Following are the reasons: 1. It has low signal strength. 2. The propagation is blocked by walls 3. It cannot use CD to avoid interference because not all participants may hear.

Here d represents the maximum range of the signals. According to the figure, computer 2 can communicate with both, 1 and 3 but computer 1 cannot communicate with computer 3 and vise versa.

docs.title: CSMA/CA
docs.text: The wireless LAN uses collision avoidance instead of collision detection. The transmitter sends very short message to the receiver. Then the receiver broadcasts to all transmitters, a short message reserving slot for that transmitter.

docs.title: Collision
docs.text: The receiver might get the request at same time. In this scenario, there is a collision at the receiver's side and no reservation is sent to the transmitters. The transmitters use backup and retry. When requests are received, the receiver selects one of them and reservation for that transmitter is sent.

docs.title: Local Talk
docs.text: Apple invented the bus topology for the LAN. The Mac computers have a default LAN port. Its speed is about 230.4Kbps. It uses CSMA/CA.

docs.title: Token Ring
docs.text: The sender holding token sends the message. It travels along the ring, passes through the computers. When it reaches the destination, the data is copied.

docs.title: Using the Token
docs.text: The token is like a permit which allows a computer to send data. After the transmission is done, the token is also passed along the ring.

docs.title: Token and Synchronization
docs.text: There is only 1 token within the whole ring. If the token is for some reason, lost, then it is re-generated by the hardware. The token gives power to a computer to transmit one frame. If all the computers are ready for transmission, then round robin access is enforced.

docs.title: IDM Token Ring
docs.text: It uses a special cable to connect the computers to the ring interface. Its speed was originally 4 Mbps but now it is up to 16 Mbps.

docs.title: FDDI
docs.text: Fiber distributed data interconnect is another ring topology. It uses fiber optics and sends data at about 100 Mbps.

docs.title: ATM (Start Network)
docs.text: Asynchronous Transferred Mode technology consists of electronic packet switches to which computers can connect

docs.title: Details
docs.text:
1. It uses fiber optic cables.
  2. It can transmit over 100 Mbps.
  3. The connection per computer uses 2 fiber optics.

docs.title: Hardware Addressing and Frame Type Identification
Hardware Addressing and Frame Type Identification
docs.text: The sending computer identifies the type of data stored inside the frame. The sending computer also uses hardware address to identify the destination computer.

docs.title: Specifying a Destination
docs.text: The hardware interface detects the frames and extracts the data from it. However, the data is sent to all the computers. There needs to be a way to specify the exact destination computer.

docs.title: Hardware Addressing
docs.text: Each device has a hardware or physical address which is included in the transmitted frame. So if the address matches, the frame is received. Otherwise, it is ignored.

docs.title: LAN Hardware AND Packet Filtering
docs.text:
The LAN interface does the following: 1. Adds hardware addresses and error detection codes to outgoing frames. 2. It obeys the CMSA/CD rules. 3. It analyzes the hardware address from incoming frames. 4. It also checks for error detection codes. 5. It may use dynamic-memory-access to copy data from the main memory. 6. It may use dynamic-memory-access to copy data to the main memory.

The frames which are not for the destination, are ignored.

docs.title: Format of Hardware Address
docs.text: It consists of numeric value and its size is selected for specific network technology. The length is 1-6 bytes.

docs.title: Assigning Hardware Address
docs.text: There are 3 types of addresses.

docs.title: Static
docs.text: In this type, the manufacturer assigns a permanent hardware address to the interface and he is also responsible in keeping them unique.

docs.title: Configurable
docs.text: These addresses can be set up by the end user either electronically by using some software or manually by using switches or jumpers.

docs.title: Dynamic
docs.text: In this one, a new address is automatically assigned when the hardware turns on.

docs.title: Broadcasting
docs.text: There is a special broadcast address as well which is captured by all the stations.
